author: acvigue

description.text:
I've recently switched all of my power strips to AmazonBasics 6-Outlet Surge Protect Power Strips and needed a good solution for holding them firmly to the wall despite plugging and unplugging things to them all the time. You can mount any power strip using screws in the back, but using a bracket is going to be more robust against tension, shear, and torsion from unplugging a variety of plugs, especially the grounded, 3-prong variety.

These parts were designed in Fusion 360, sliced in Simplify3D, and printed on a Prusa i3 MK2S.There are 2 screw holes for Bracket 1, 2 holes for Bracket 2, and 1 hole for the optional cable manager. The screws I used are #8 1" Phillips Flat Head Wood Screw, 18-8 SS with Black Xylan Coating.

title: (Modular) Square-Tiled Tabletop Board
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
*Quick Update: Modified the .stls so that they are better oriented for printing upon download. Didn't notice until they were uploaded

I've been working on a new boardgame idea for a few months now since I got my printer. While the game itself is still being tested and modified, I thought I might some files I've remixed to make a modular, chess-like board.

The base tile holder is remixed from ThinkerThing's Open Board Game Hex Brick. The tiles which fit in the holder are based off various sources;

  • the grass tile is also from ThinkerThing's Open Board Game
  • the dirt tile was cut down a bit from der_graue's Crackled Floor Plate
  • the mountain center piece was placed on a tile base, borrowed from dutchmogul's Cyvasse

Overall I think the board came out better than expected, each of the tiles fit snug in their holders and I can see the potential for some really interesting boards getting made from this.

The board is scaled to be about 6mm tall, each tile measures 29.8mm x 29.8mm so if you want to make your own tiles they will need to be created at this size to fit.

Since the tiles are fairly detailed, I recommend you print them in the upright position. This will cause many more layers, but the Z-axis provides better quality for such fine details.

If you use these tiles to make a board, please share your creation! I'd love to see what gets made from these!

I used regular spray paint to get the grass green and the dirt brown. Painting the tiles took about 3 quick coats.

My larger board (pictured) is a 9x9 board used in the game I am building. I used small magnets to keep the board together which work great! I just drilled some small holes in the side and gorilla glued the magnets in (make sure you get the polarity in the right direction!).

comments.text: This looks awesome! I actually made a modular board(for the cyvasse game) but it was out of puzzle style pieces,  this is a much more elegent solution!  Out of curiosity, the standard board from the dutchmogul original set is a 5x5 grid,  i noticed the Quarter board file is only a 4x4,  but it looks like in your preview pic you had a 5x5 grid?
comments.author: rabidninjawombat

comments.text: Thanks for the kind words! I haven't actually got around to printing and playing the Cyvasse game yet, but the board shown in the pictures above is being used to prototype a game that I have been designing. The dimensions used in that board are 9 x 9 with an impassable center object. So my quarter boards were 4 x 5, but I didn't think very many people were trying to make that size board. Seems they are usually 8 x 8 or 10 x 10.

author: TheIdNerfer

title: Hot-end insulation for Raise3D single extruder printers N1/N2/N2+.

description.text:
This modification insulates the hot-end very effectively (3 x 1 mm ceramic fiber insulation on all sides of hot-end) and reduces the radiative heat transfer from the hot-end to the printed model.
The power needed to heat the hot-end is significantly reduced and the fans ability to cool the cold side of the hot-end is much better, thereby reducing the risk of soft filament clogging in the PTFE pipe. The stronger model blower is very useful for printing PLA.

The modification requires some metal sheet work. The 0.5 mm aluminium can be cut with a pair of scissors. You also need to cut many small pieces of Ceramic Fiber Insulation to size.

The modification includes the following parts:

  • Duct for a 40 mm radial blower that gives a strong air flow around the nozzle tip.
  • Optimized duct for the standard 35 mm fan for the hot-end thermal barrier.
  • Heat-shield made from 0.5 mm aluminum, that also keeps thermal insulation material in place.

Further materials needed:

  • 6 pcs. Heat-set M3 threaded brass inserts for Ø4 mm holes.
  • 7 pcs. M3 x 6 mm pan-head screws
  • 2 pcs. M3 x 20 mm cap-head or pan-head screws
  • 1 pcs. Renren3D Ball Bearing 12V Brushless Motor Blower 40x40x20
  • Ceramic Fiber Insulation 1 mm thick
  • 0.5 mm Aluminum plate, semi hard

The blower duct is not easy to print. Support must be used both from the build plate and internally in the model. As the duct has thin walls, I recommend using the dynamic extrusion width feature of Simplify3D rev. 4, although not strictly necessary.
As the plastic is very close to the hot-end, the material must be ABS or PC. PLA will not stand the heat.

After the modification, PID parameters and regulator open loop settings need to be changed in Marlin configuration.h file.
If you don't know how to compile new Marlin firmware, then don't make this modification.
Here are the new settings needed:

  • DEFAULT_Kp 14.0
  • DEFAULT_Ki 0.2
  • DEFAULT_Kd 200.0
  • BANG_MAX 128
  • PID_MAX 255
  • PID_FUNCTIONAL_RANGE 30

These settings will result in almost no temperature overshoot when raising the temperature from e.g. 25 °C to 210 °C.
With these settings, the regulator is almost insensible to starting and stopping filament extrusion and turning on and off the model cooling blower.
The attached plot of the temperature settling curve includes starting and stopping filament extrusion and turning on and off the model cooling blower, after the temperature settled to 210 °C, but this is barely visible in the plot. In the second plot the temperature is raised to 260 °C and further to 300 °C. The settling times are very short.

This is a first attempt at a vacuum form mold set for the Sinclair ZX80 computer. The ZX80's case was originally vacuum formed from polystyrene sheets, only later becoming injection molded.

This is an attempt to produce simple molds that can be made to replace the original cases which have become very brittle due to their age, or for a new ZX80 replica. The Sinclair ZX80 computer was produced by a company called "Science Of Cambridge" (Later renamed Sinclar Research) in 1980 and was powered by the Zilog Z80 Microprocessor and utilized 4k of Rom and 1k of Ram.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/9HX4z2TPCyo

Picture the scene... you arrive at work and, while your PC is booting up, decide to make yourself a nice cup of tea. So you wander to the kitchen, and open the fridge, only to discover that someone has used all your milk again - oh no! With a look of despondency, you return to your office, and resolve to find a solution to this problem.

This is a locking milk bottle cap, which requires a removable "key" to be able to open. The idea is that the cap rotates freely without the key, making it difficult to open the bottle. When the key is inserted, the cap locks and can be removed or refitted easily.

Now your milk is a little bit safer in the communal fridge at work...

For food safety, this is designed to accept a standard milk bottle cap which needs to be glued into the 3D printed cap after assembly.

Other parts required:

  • 1x countersunk screw M3x10 (to secure the central hub)
  • 2x metal shafts 3x18mm (these form the pins in the "key")

Drill through part 3 with a 3mm drill, and drill through the two outer holes in part 1 with a 3mm drill.

Test fit the milk bottle cap in part 2 (while it is still easy to remove by pushing a pen through the central hole). This is designed to fit caps with 40mm outside diameter, and 11.5mm height. These seem to be fairly standard in the UK at least.

Assemble parts 1,2,3 together, filing as needed so that part 2 rotates very freely in part 1. Assuming it does, secure part 3 with M3x10 screw (do not overtighten). If everything still rotates freely, fix part 3 permanently with a small amount of glue and the M3x10 screw. Spread glue around the inside of part 2, keeping well away from the central hub. Insert the milk bottle cap firmly and leave the glue to set.

Take the two 3mm by 18mm shafts, and gently tap them into the key (knurled handwheel), which should leave 10mm projecting out of the handle.

To loosen or tighten the cap, the two pins in the key (knurled handwheel) are pushed through the holes in the upper cap (part 1), to engage with the two channels in lower section (part 2).

description.text:
This is a simple pen drawing bot. It is like a T-Bot (AxiDraw), but I moved the motors to the middle. This has the advantage of making the machine a little smaller and way cooler, in my opinion. See the video.

I made mine really small, so it can fit in my backpack, but it is easily scaled up by using longer rods and a longer belt. With that said, the X axis rods will start to get springy above 200mm long.

The firmware is a special version of Grbl. The only change is the spindle PWM is used to raise and lower the pen. It also has the CoreXY features of Grbl enabled.

You can use just about any CNC controller that can run 2 steppers and a servo, but I made a custom controller that sits in the center and makes the wiring super clean. A limited qty are for sale on Tindie.

See my blog post blog post on this for further details.
Follow me on Twitter for announcement.

LulzBot

Servo tester replacement case.

The servo testers are inexpensive and readily available on-line. The acetate cover falls apart very quickly with use. The case make the item much more appropriate for everyday use.
The acetate cover is reused as labels on the completed project.

EK2-0907 Servo Tester Server Electronic Speed Controller

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Instructions:

  1. Remove the knob from the potentiometer on top of the servo tester. It should just pull off.
  2. Carefully remove the servo tester from the flimsy acetate cover. Try not to damage it as parts will be used as labels on the finished case.
  3. Place two spare servo plugs on the two external sets of servo pins. This will ensure that when the tester is seated within the case that it is correctly spaced.
  4. Install the servo tester onto the case top cover. Replace the knob to secure it. The tester should sit evenly on the cover.
  5. Ensure that the tester is in the correct orientation and that it sits within the case base.
  6. Put ample hot melt adhesive on the bottom of the tester. Place the tester back in the base. Ensure that it sits correctly. Make any positional adjustment before the hot melt sets.
  7. Remove the knob and secure the top cover with the minimum amount super glue.
  8. Trim the acetate cover so the they can be used as labels on the case.
  9. Replace the knob and check that the tester is working as intended.

For all parts except lock top, I recommend 100% infill for maximum strength.

Step 1: Spring Lever
Place the spring lever on the pin shown. The spring lever should move freely on the pin with minimal friction. If the spring lever moves stiffly or does not fit, clean the pin and hole with sand paper or file until a smooth fit is achieved. WARNING: any forceful twisting on the pin could make it break off.

Step 2: Tongue Placement
Before placing the tongue, rub it generously with bar soap on all sides to reduce friction. Place it in the slot with the end groove at the approximate location shown.

Step 3: Spring Placement
Place the spring as shown so that the top fits into the groove on the tongue, and the bottom is pushed down as far as possible into the groove without damaging it.

Step 4: Function Check
Push on the spring lever as shown and ensure that the beveled end of the tongue retracts as shown. When the spring lever is released, everything snaps back to the original position. If it does not, try rubbing more bar soap on the tongue, and possibly on the bottom of the spring lever.

Step 5: Shackle Placement
Place the shackle on the pin shown. The shackle should be able to twist freely on the pin. If there is excess friction, clean the pin and/or hole with sand paper or a file.
Step 6: Function Check
Twist the shackle into the closed position. It should snap into place, with the beveled end of the tongue locking it. Place the key on the pin below the spring lever and twist as shown. With the tongue retracted as shown, the shackle can be swung open. Lock and unlock several times to ensure there is no catching.

Step 7: Key fit check
Before putting the lock top on the lock, insert the key through the key hole to make sure it fits.
Step 8: Putting on the Lock Top
Install the lock top on the 4 pins shown. The pins should fit tightly, but if the fit is too tight, clean the pins with sandpaper or a file, being careful not to remove too much material.

Note: once the top is placed, it is difficult to remove without breaking the pins.

description.text:
My Solar scope has an odd space between the holes for the dovetail mounting. I drilled my bar to fit but the dill bit slipped and the hole was slightly off. my alinement was never right. So I made one to fit my solar scope.

This model is easy to tweak. So if you want to print one, just message me with where you want your holes and how long you want it. I'll gladly adjust the model to your specs. I have also added a hole for installing a 3/8-1/4 thread adapter so it can be mounted to a tripod.

This is something you want to print out of abs and make it as solid as possible. I was skeptical myself about this as my solar scope is about $3000. But it seems to hold rater well.

title: Bluetooth radio conversion for vintage radio - National AB-235

description.text:
I found a neat old National AB-235 solid state radio at a swap meet this spring for $5. Since it wasn't working anymore, I thought it'd make a great bluetooth radio for the beach.

To keep the original speaker and all of its tinny charm, I needed more depth for electronics. My solution was to create a new back piece with my 3D printer that was about .325" deeper. I added through holes for the electronics, a 9V battery holder, and an opening for a switch.

Here's the receiver I used
https://www.amazon.com/INSMA-TDA7492P-Bluetooth-Amplifier-Amplifiers/dp/B01KFYUVVS

description.text:
I made another hose mender and although that one does work I have some cheapo HF hose clamps which end up bending while I try to tighten down all the way. Link for my other hose mender. https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1476241

This hose mender will fix standard garden hose with 5/8" ID. If needed larger or smaller just use a tool like Cura and re-size entire object proportionately.

Inside hole for water flow is 8mm. The primary "pipe" diameter is 12mm with large bumps at the top and bottom being 14mm.

I printed at 0.3mm mm and 100% infill and brim. I am able to severely tighten down the cheapo HF hose clamps without bending and getting no leaks at all.

Rafts:

No

No

0.3

100

Notes:

Use brim and no supports.

description.text: A caliper holder for your pegboard! 'Nuff said. Prints fine support free in standard orientation assuming your printer can bridge decently...

I have spent several hours making the Atlas files available on thingiverse much more printer friendly. All of these files should be 100% download and print ready. These files are meant to be printed and then super-glued together into position. Previously the arms and legs in particular were made of many small parts that were not touching, the torso had many geometric errors, and the pieces were not made to fit together simply. I have remedied this to a point now that you should be able to print each part without modification and just glue them together in a pose of your choosing.

*note that the "bit1" and "bit2" glue onto the bottom of the torso, and are included as different files just to help you print the torso a bit "shorter" and start on a common sense flat spot. Should save some plastic and time.

I printed each part at 75% scale and ended up with a 7.5" tall battlemech.

Repetier host 2.0.5 slices each of these files without error.

All model credits to MWO owners: https://mwomercs.com/ I claim no ownership of the model geometry. Just trying to make it an easier print with less work required for other people :)

you should also check out http://battletechgame.com/

title: Custom Adjustable Z Endstop for Prusa I3X or I3XL

description.text: This was designed specifically for the DIY Tech Shop Prusa I3X.  There are many adjustable Z endstops, but I wanted one that fit perfectly and was completely reversible.  This works perfectly.

For this thing you must also supply an endstop holder to match your particular endstop. For the DIY Tech Shop version, this endstop holder was used by me https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:13353. It has two mounting holes, I drilled 2 more so the switch can be mounted in any direction. Print off the part I made. You will need to supply the following hardware.
1 3x20mm socket cap wrap threads with 1 layer teflon tape wrapped on it
1 3x30mm socket cap
1 3mm washer
1 aluminum spacer 1/4 x 1 inside threads for #6 - cut down length to 20mm - purchased at local hardware store
1 3mm nut Note: The aluminum spacer has threads inside, but they are not necessary. In this case the 3mm goes thru the threads. If you have a suitable spacer withouth threads it can be used as well. The picture above shows all the parts. The nut is already installed in the nut trap above. You will need to ream the holes slightly and the nut needs a bit of friendly persuasion, but I wanted the nut to be tight and not move. Then you assemble. The spacer get pushed in the larger hole, flat with the face opposite the nut trap. Then screw in the 3x20mm about 1/2 way into the nut in the trap. Remove socket cap from the lower right of the x motor mount. Use a 3x30mm and 3mm washer and put the screw thru the aluminum spacer, push the spacer in the motor mount opening, and screw the 3x30mm securely. Ensure it is vertical. Position your endstop below this, so that the screw head contacts the switch. Now you simply adjust your z level by turning the screw. The teflon tape provides enough drag that the screw will stay where it is adjusted. This will allow you to very precisely adjust the Z axis.
Enjoy

comments.text: What about making it so you completely replace the left x carriage/motor mount with your piece built into it so that you don't need the aluminum spacer? Just a thought. Cool piece!

author: n9jcv

print_settings.Notes:: if you rotate the "red dot top" 10° around the X axis, it'll sit flat.

description.text:
Here is a (almost) fully functional red dot sight. it's not like i'm trying to outdo everyone elses guns at the works Christmas party. It's designed on a Nerf stryfe but would probably fit other stuff too.

When i say almost, i haven't got the concave lens that eliminates the parallax and keeps the dot on target when you move your eye around. It just uses a flat piece of perspex which doesn't matter as the Nerf gun is anything but accurate. Plus i don't have a red LED so mine's white. Other than that it's flawless. If you can sort out a curved screen good on you.

I have scavenged everything needed out one of those POS solar garden lights from last year that no longer works (it's only the battery that's dead). if you get one with a sliding switch you'll be golden.

Shout out to Andy Williams on GrabCAD who provided the "Red/Green Dot Holographic Sight". it's an AD inventor model that i couldn't open but i was able to view the STL in Solidworks to get a few dimensions. nice one Andy.

Notes:

Black plastic and a brim is probably a good idea.

if you rotate the "red dot top" 10° around the X axis, it'll sit flat.

(step 1) important
you will need to drill a hole for the light to shine through. if you drill from the inside out, there is sort of a pilot hole in the bottom of the big hole for the LED. start small and get bigger if required. i have drilled a 1.5mm hole.

(step 2) you need to remove the tabs circled in red on the base part, they're only for support as i use slicer.

(step 3) you may need to paint the inside and/or the outside black to hide the glow of the LED through the plastic.

(step 4) glue the sliding switch up font so that the handle bit protrudes through the hole. once dry, you can assemble the two halves of the dial so when you twist the dial it flips the switch. damn right it's working dial on top!
next, you may need to extend the wire from the switch to the LED if it's short. glue the battery terminals into the base and insert one AA and screw the two halves of the case together with some M3 screws.

(step 5) now the hard part, the screen.
you'll want some reasonably thick scratch free something. I've finally used some 1.5mm perspex but was thinking of possibly cutting up one of those clear plastic Christmas baubles with stuff in it for that magic concave shape.
anyway, trace around the inside of the frame and cut it out. then sand down to a perfect fit. you're going for a screen with a slight backwards tilt almost vertical. you'll know it's right when the reflection of the LED is in the middle. glue the screen in once done painting.

JOB DONE!!

title: Side mounted spool holder Flashforge Creator PRO 2016

description.text:
I needed a better solution for the back mounted spool holders on the Flashforge Creator Pro 2016.
I searched but didn't find any that suited my needs.
So I designed this one to be easy to attach using no screws or other fixing method.
I designed it so that the actual spool holding part could be exchangeable to fit different spools.

Ive included the Fusion files for the arm and spool holder should you like to modify it.
Im new to using Fusion so should there be anything strange in the designfile, be aware.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,2 mm

Infill:

30 %

Notes:

I printed mine using a raft to avoid any warping.
I designed it to use the larger flat surfaces facing downwards, but you are free to place the parts however you see fit.
I designed it to use very little supports, but some are needed.
Designed to be interlocking and to need any other method of fixing, like screws etc.

Depending on the printer settings and filament quality some sanding might be needed.
I needed just a tiny bit on the arm to make it slide like I wanted it too.

I have designed a silencer for the G36C airsoft gun in a way, that you can replace your battery without removing the silencer. It has the same drop like shape like the front of the gun.

Two parts. One is a 14 mm counter clockwise base, and the other is the silencer itself. You can tight the silencer to the base with a M4 nut, at the top of the silencer.

This is my first 3D printed object in thingiverse, so go easy on me :)

Printed in PLA 190/60 degrees, 0.4 mm nozzle, with print speed of 40mm. For me the silencer had enough grip to the table, so no need for support or brim. Both part printed vertically.

The design were made with Tinkercad.

title: Creative Live! Webcam Mount for Prusa i3 MK2S
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a mount specifically for the Creative Live! Cam Sync HD webcam. This mount clips to the X End Idler of the Prusa i3 Mk2S. The camera moves with the Z axis, so the vertical angle is always the same relative to the currently printed layer.

This is a first version, time will tell if it needs modification. The video quality of the webcam itself is pretty bad, so I wouldn't recommend buying one just to use this model. But if you (as I do) happen to own this type of camera, this model might be useful.

You could most likely use this with octoprint (the camera works out of the box with Linux), or you could just set up a web stream to follow your prints remotely.

Also check out my LED strip mount for this printer, it provides good lighting for the webcam: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2577287

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

300um

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Printed this in PLA, works just fine.

Clip the mount to the X End Idler (right side), it should snap into place easily.

Push the flat clip thingy of the camera into its slot. It should be snug and firm. Move the X axis all the way to the right, and slide the camera mount up or down until you find the sweet spot where it doesn't touch the nozzle fan cover.

Make sure the usb cable can move freely and doesn't snag when moving the Z axis.

Note that the camera mount is a bit difficult to remove, you can use a flat head screwdriver to remove the notch that sits in the bearing groove. Be careful not to dislodge the bearings.

author: SubSite

description.text: Le moulin de Cintegabelle version porte-clefs

Okay, I love the original, but changing batteries just isn't an easy option. I did see a remix where someone made it far easier to access the batteries to change them, but that still means changing them and paying for new batteries after they run down.

I searched around and found a little board that could be modified to charge rechargeable 2032 batteries and made it all work together. The rose stays lit for over 20 hours on a charge, then just plug it in for a few hours and you're good to go again!

The Basics

Okay, so you need a couple of items for this rose.

I went with tiny spdt switches found on ebay cheap: Switches

Then of course rechargeable Batteries Not that you need 24 of them.

You will need 330 ohm surface mount resistors

The charging boards like these TP4056 are needed. There are many of them on Ebay and they are cheaper in China. Just look at the board layout in the picture. I've ordered them from a few places and they seem to all be the same for changing the resistor for charging rate.

Once you have the parts, the hardest part is changing the resistor on the charging board. I definitely needed a magnifying glass and helping hands to do it! I changed the resistor according to this Instructable though there are tutorials all over the internet for the process. Honestly, I can see this card being used for many other projects now that I know about it!

Solder the battery's positive to the center post of the switch. Then one switch post goes to the charger's battery positive and the other goes to the LED's cathode. I used a 220 ohm resistor between the switch and the cathode as a current limiter.

The anode, battery negative on the charger, and the negative terminal on the battery all get connected together.

Assembly was easy. I use a 3d printing pen like a hot glue gun to hold the board and switch in place. I then put a scrap piece of heat shrink between the board and the battery for insulation. I also use the 3d pen to attach the flower head to the stem, though if you make a mistake in your wiring and don't find it first you pretty much have to destroy the plastic to get it apart.

Anyway, I charge my flowers on a laptop now, or a low amp USB wall adaptor. No need to change batteries anymore!

Stem Remix from Original

Remixed stem to allow access to mini USB cable for charging.
Enhanced opening for switch for more secure holding of switch.

The guide tab is the only piece that needs to be super glued on- although it is recommended that you use a couple drops for assembling each piece. A modeling triangle (ruler can be used) will assist in ensuring the entire rocket is straight upon drying.

The print file is designed with its own break-away support under the fins, but support is still needed for the motor retainer.

Do not use an engine higher than a C6-5
(Please be careful if firing the rocket and take all necessary flight precautions. Due to the nature of 3-D printing and the minimal flight tests we ask you be cognizant of the hazards.)

I remixed https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:256966 because it was pretty difficult to print. All I did was cut it in half so I can print it easier and just glue the two pieces together. Not sure if slicers can do that, but that's how I did it.

This is a solution to the fact that the Tronxy x8 has no x axis belt tensioner, and the belt rubs on the bearing of the extruder carriage when using the bearing as-is. The other x axis belt tensioners I've found on thingiverse do not solve the issue of the rubbing, but this one does, and uses the leverage of the cavity on the z axis part, at the expense of some material. If you find an even smaller bearing, then you can reclaim some of the lost build area.

Version 1.2:
added actual tensioner bolt adjuster. insert M3 nut at the end and use a 30mm M3 bolt to tighten.

Bearing M3 nut now has it's own recess to sit in without compromising the strength of the bearing axle.

Printing PLA with 15 percent infill has been tested and is strong.

Printed on blue tape with a 3mm brim, at 215C hot end, and 50C heated bed and no supports, no rafts, sliced with Cura.

Installation note:

I recommend to unfasten the z axis lead screw so you don't knick it with your philips head screwdriver while tensioning.

If you have an even smaller bearing, it's probably better, since the belt ends up being about 2mm away from the smooth rod underneath the assembly, which is actually much better than the belt rubbing under the carriage bearing mount.
I designed this to protect the battery contacts on the LP-E17 battery for my Canon t6i camera. The holder will also work on the "decoy batteries" that are similarly sized.

title: Lorenz Attractor - Customized
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Customized model of the Lorenz Attractor. Included are two files, one with a flat face for easy FDM printing, and a smaller, high resolution model suitable for SLA or SLS printing.

About the Lorenz Attractor, from Urban Reininger:
"Chaos theory scientists often like to use this model to show how small changes in initial conditions can result in unanticipated behavior is systems...the Lorenz System can be tinkered with to see how small changes can have unpredictable results."
More info about this model: http://urbanatwork.com/2015/12/09/simple-lorenz-system-in-openscad/

From Wikipedia:
"The Lorenz system is a system of ordinary differential equations first studied by Edward Lorenz. It is notable for having chaotic solutions for certain parameter values and initial conditions. In particular, the Lorenz attractor is a set of chaotic solutions of the Lorenz system which, when plotted, resemble a butterfly or figure eight."
More info on the Lorenz system: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lorenz_system

description.text:
I modified Yvan's RAMPS case to fit my needs. The nice thing is you can print each side flat so it is easy to print.
I modified the lid for a 50mm cooling fan but included Yvan's lid for a 40mm fan. I also added a end plate that has all the holes for the RAMPS connectors. I like it best with transparent filament so you can see the blinking lights on the Arduino and Ramps Boards through the sides. Mine is not really intentionally multi colored but my Kossel build has taken so long that I printed pieces at different times with different plastics. description.text:
The Digiloom ships with 2 shuttles, and 8 colors of weaving string. Why not put all of the string onto it's own shuttle though? I set out to create 6 more shuttles so my daughter could spend more time making, and less time winding string onto shuttles.

This is a pretty close approximation of the stock shuttle. I added two teardrop holes to secure the string that's not being used.

Clean off any raft, and de-burr. The holes are best de-burred with a small drill bit.

title: Bag Clip with a Tight Seal

description.text:
This is our attempt to create a better bag clip. Popular bag clips are easy to open/close: like this one, or they may provide possibly a better seal, but we find them more difficult to use: like this one.

In this design, we try to create an easy to use clip with an exceptional seal. Not recommended to hold liquids like on out main photo, but it should keep your potato chips quite fresh.

PRINT

  • Prints assembled.
  • Sizes show working length in mm, final print is 30 mm longer.
  • 0.2 mm layer or smaller. You’ll need at least 50% fill for strength, but don’t go over 80%.
  • DON’T print any supports.
  • Raft: optional, we don’t use them.
  • If tolerances are too tight, try to print in the highest resolution, and if that doesn’t work, let us know in the comments section, we’ll try to publish another version with looser tolerances.

See our titanium binary carabiners and free-standing hybrid candles at our site iomaa.com.

Enjoy

title: Tesla Model S Door Handle Fix/Prop for Non-Retracting Handles

description.text:
The Model S's retracting door handles, particularly the early revisions, are notorious for failing. If your Model S door handle stops retracting, you can attach this to it to use your door until it is fixed.

Directions:

  1. Use the tool to pry your Model S handle out from the vehicle.
  2. Fit the big loop of the plastic prop over the top side of the handle.
  3. Use the tool to pry the small loop of the prop beneath the bottom of the handle, and release it in place. It's easiest to do this by working edge to edge rather than all at once.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.38mm

Infill:

15

Notes:

This print has very loose tolerances. It should work fine on any printer with any reasonable settings.

I prefer PLA for its flexibility but I imagine ABS will work fine, too.

author: freerobby

description.text:
My son (yes, he's into things like that) broke his store bought magic wand, so I made him another.

it's about 100mm wide at 100%. I don't recomend printing smaller than that, plus the shaft won't fit in the receptacle....

it's two halves, mirrored, of the same part, that you glue back to back. I printed in PLA, glued with crazy glue. that way you get the diamond shapes on both halves (printing all in one would result in a flat side and a nice side).

print takes about 45 mins or so and 3.5 meters of materials. I'd recommend printing at no more than .15mm layers, because of all the small details, it looks notchy like I did, at .25mm

For the shaft, I made the hole 1/4 or 6mm, so that you can put a stick that size in it (I got myself a bunch of wooden dowels just like that at the dollar store).

PLEASE hit like, collect or whatever applies. I made it is even better!

title: Mic Stand Holder for Samsung Galaxy S7 (in a phone case)

description.text: I needed to do some "hands-free" filming with my phone, so I made this so that I could hold my phone with a mic stand while I was filming. It was designed to work with a Galaxy S7 inside an Incipio phone case, but if you adjust the X and/or Y size of the model before printing you should be able to get it to work with your phone as well. (Suggestion: only print the first couple millimeters of layers, just enough to get the shape of the "claw", then stop the print and test it against your phone. If it doesn't fit right, change your print scale and try again.)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Notes:

Change the X and/or Y scale in your slicer to adjust this to your own phone's dimensions if it doesn't work as-is. Also, print with a filament that has some flex to it (PETG is a good choice) if at all possible.

print_settings.Notes:: The Tower Window Piece I had a heck of a time getting to print right, and still have a curved back to smoothly attach to the can. I finally wound up using supports and printing it at a 12% angle to get something workable - but I have a lot of ridges.

description.text:
NOTE: An updated version of this project can be found here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2610039

Deep in the Golad Mountains of Domaar, in the vale of Prin Guls between the Night Elven realm of Khimzul, and the High Elven realm of Auborlon stand the watchtowers of Prin Guls as a first line of defense against a Night Elven attack.

This is a set of files designed to turn an ordinary Pringles chip can into a piece of 28mm wargaming terrain with a vaguely elven theme. It is the first piece of a planned modular elven fortress using a combination of 3d printed pieces, Pringles cans, Foam core and card stock. The top parapets are sized just big enough that 7 minis on 1" round bases can fit on the top.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

20%

Notes:

The Tower Base, Tower Top Corbel piece, and Tower Top Parapet piece are designed to print without supports, but your mileage may vary. I don't know how to re-orient the stl's for correct printing in anything other than my slicer software (Pruse Control) - but basically, rotate the the flattest parts to the bed.

The Tower Window Piece I had a heck of a time getting to print right, and still have a curved back to smoothly attach to the can. I finally wound up using supports and printing it at a 12% angle to get something workable - but I have a lot of ridges.

Step 0: Note

Since Thingiverse keeps losing my pictures, I've uploaded a PDF of these instructions with PHOTOS to the files.

Step 1: Preparing the Pringles can

The sizing on the Tower Base and Tower Top Corbel pieces are sized to fit around the metal base of the can. This leaves a bit of a gap around the card board that my intention is to be able to use to slip a piece of textured cardstock in between. However, the rolled card board top of the can that the plastic lid fits to is too big, and needs to be carefully cut off.

The next thing you'll want to do is use a marker or pen to put a vertical line on the can so that you can line up the top and bottom pieces. You can use some sort of marking tool or square to do this, but in most cases, the nutrition box and ingredients text of the label itself provides a nice reference. I just lined a ruler up against that, and used a Sharpie.

If you're going to use some sort of card stock or paper around the tube, now is the time to put it on. Makes sure you have some sort of vertical line as a reference.

Step 2: Gluing Everything together.

I used 5 minute epoxy to glue everything together. I personally like to orient the can upside down so that the tower can be lifted to place miniatures underneath to show they're inside. If you're worried about the thing tipping over, you can use the can right side up, and fill the bottom with a layer of sand or plaster to weight things down.

When gluing the top parapet piece to the top corbel piece, you'll notice there are three small holes in each piece. These are designed to use short 5mm pieces of 1.75 filament as "keys" so that the two pieces are properly centered.

Glue one or more of the window pieces around the outside as desired.

After gluing, you'll probably need to use something to gap fill because of the extra tolerance I left around the can.

Step 3: Prime and Paint

Prime and Paint as desired.

Step 4: Game!

Use it in a game, and share a picture here using the I Made One button.

All of the pieces were pieces were modeled in Fusion 360.

The chips in the Pringles can were eaten at a previous game session.

author: ashes2000

title: Modular Hobby Paint Rack - Outside Corner

description.text:
Fourth of the modular paint racks to store and organize hobby paints. This one is an outside corner section. I designed this to hold Vallejo or Reaper dropper paint bottles. I will be adding more shelf layouts to hold paints such as Miniataire, GW and others!

Capacity:

  • 20 dropper bottles (Vallejo, Reaper, Army Painter)
  • 18 Minitaire bottles

Dropper style bottles can be stored in the upright or inverted position. The Reaper paints in the upright position have a little play in them but will still be held without falling over or getting trapped. I designed it more for the inverted position as that is the way I hold my paints to prevent tip dry out.

You will need to print the following to assemble one unit:

One of the following:

  • LeftSide
  • RightSide
  • BottomFront-OutsideCorner
  • BottomRear-OutsideCorner
  • Shelf1-OutsideCorner-(bottle style)
  • Shelf2-OutsideCorner-(bottle style)
  • Shelf3-OutsideCorner-(bottle style)
  • Shelf4-OutsideCorner-(bottle style)

Luckily these pieces would fight on the print bed but if it doesn't on yours you may have to split them and glue the two halves together. Assemble with the tabs and slots. I would also suggest glue just to be safe in case you have to move it even though the fit should be pretty tight. Further details will be in the assembly instructions.

Hope you enjoy this and it gives you more options to tidy up your painting desk.

Other units in the series:
Large Straight - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2531450
Small Straight - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2549451
Inside Corner - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2543779
Tool Holder - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2601038

Upcoming:

  • Assembly Instructions
  • Additional shelves for more paint brands

  2. bottom frame of the plane
  3. propeller
  4. Nose of the plane

Overview The model is about 19.5cm long with a wingspan of about 26cm. It has good details and requires a lot of assembly, just like what you will see on a real airplane. Works best if you print the frame with wood! Looks even more like a real one!

Extra materials
  • Paper, used to wrap the wings and fuselage.
  • Super glue, you will need a lot of it.
  • Aluminum foil, to wrap the nose of the plane.
  • Tape, to connect the flaps.

title: Ultra-low profile IKEA mirror clips for K8200

description.text:
All the other mirror clips I tried didn't work very well because they were either too high so that they took away quite much printing space or were knocked off by the fan nozzle or because they opened up too much one they got warm on the heat bed.  
These ones are only 1.5 mm higher than the mirror surface and clip into the holes in the heat bed carrier. Since I have these on my printer, none of them came loose or anything else - and I can use almost all of the mirror surface to print on.

Print at 100% infill and clip at least 4 of them, 2 on each side, onto the heat bed / mirror stack. Mirror needs to be well-centered for them to work as they are quite short on top of the mirror (which is intended).  
I additionally secured my mirror with some hot-glue around the edges which helps to hold it in place but gets loose without the clips over time.

title: spring (6.2mm inner, 9mm outer, 10mm height, with rings at top and bottom)

description.text:
made this remix so it's smaller and has a top and bottom ring.

print it really slow (I printed 1500mm/sec) and quite cold (I did 185 instead of my usual 195-200 for PLA), or else you never build in height, it just droops. Also, make certain the layers are as thin as possible, or else the hangovers are going to be bigger the thicker the layer. I did .15mm and that was too much. go as small as your printer allows for something this small.

should scale up well, probably not down though, it's already quite small.

good luck.

PLEASE like it or collect Ir or I Made IT, whatever applies..

title: sd card holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
this was designed to bolt to a 2020 rail using m4x10mm with m4 washers and t-nuts. The original design was messed up so i redesigned it this time with a window so you can see what card is in there. i am printing with eSun PLA+ at 235c with a dual 5015 fang fan setup. the bed is set at 65c until half the part is reached, then it drops to 50c to reduce the time required to remove the part from the heated bed. I also use hairspray to help adhere this part to the bed. i am printing 9 at a time, it fits my tevo bed pretty good.The file contains just one copy.

print with no supports. use parts cooling fan at maximum before you reach the layers at the top.
i used sketchup to design this part and corrected any errors with netfabb to ensure the model was closed with no errors.

author: wonmurk

title: Flexion Extruder adapter for Xinkebot Orca2 Cygnus

description.text:
Directions for adapter:

  1. Print solid for maximum strength. Remove all supports.
  2. Remove the hotend from the original extruder by removing the 4 bolts from the cover assembly. (You have to remove the aluminum light hood first by unscrewing the front top two bolts. It might be good to use some blue tape to secure the LED strip to the hood while you're manipulating things as the LED soldering can break easily).
  3. Assemble the hotend as desired. I used the E3D block and sock upgrade. The original hotend has a long stem of PTFE tubing coming out the top. If it has moved, it cannot be pulled back up, you will have to remove the locking nut and advance it all the way through (toward the nozzle end with the heat break removed) and re-insert it after placing the heat break and nozzle assembly back. Advance the tube as far as it will go. It should go up into the bottom of the Flexion Extruder. I did not make a "fish mouth" as is the configuration of the provided PTFE tubes in the Flexion Extruder kit, and it seems to work fine.
  4. Drop nuts in holes under the front of where the stepper motor mounts. These are for mounting the magnetic extruder mounting plate.
  5. Use long bolt that came with extruder kit to attach the right side of the stepper motor with the extruder already mounted on it. You will need 2 washers, make it barely finger-tight so you can still move the stepper motor.
  6. Mount the lower left corner of the motor using the original bolt that mounted the lower left corner of the motor and hold the motor so it is as far right as possible, then tighten the bolts.
  7. Make sure the extruder swings easily when changing the settings on the wheel (1 through 4) without bumping up against any part of the adapter. The extruder assembly should not touch the adapter at any setting which is how it was designed. If there was any overhanging filament during printing touching the extruder assembly, remove the motor, file or sand overhang off, making sure to remove any dust before putting the motor/extruder back on.
  8. Attach electronics mount (looks like a goal-post). Make sure you are using the correct (shorter) counter-sunk bolts.
  9. Attach the top bolts securing the terminal board. Do not forget to use the original black plastic spacer between the terminal board and the electronics mount.
  10. Attach hot end cooling fan (label toward cooling fins). Do not overtighten bolts.
  11. Attach blower fan for hotend duct loosely. Don't forget the original small nylon spacer.
  12. Attach Z-sensor plate on the left of the extruder. Carefully take note of the terminal numbers the wires are connected to and disconnect them. Then carfully remove the assembly, and thread the wires into the Flexion Extruder adapter and install in the same way it was in the original.
  13. Attach magnetic extruder mounting plate, being careful to line up the blower motor and duct. Tighten the blower fan bolt.
  14. Attach the light hood.

--note that the adapter in the photo is a slightly earlier version. The final version is in the photo with the extruder mounted on it.

description.text:
Have you found that the leveling knob can be loosing along the printing when the bed is moving back and forth? Using the big knob you downloaded from thingiverse and this knob plug can easily solve the problem.
Of course, you need one plug for each knob. Totally four plugs.
One more thing, this plug will reduce your bed leveling frequency dramatically because one major reason why you have to level your bed is because the knob loose away during previous printing.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2508323
This is the leveling knob that work with this plug.

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100

Notes:

Once, I printed a thing of high 5.5mm and ended up with only 5.3mm. What was worse, one of the leveling knob fell down on the desk. Then, I realized that along the printing, the leveling knob is getting looser and looser when the bed is moving back and forth and that's why the bumped shell sometime show on the printing.
To stop the loosing of the knob, simply put a plug to prevent it. I did this a month ago and the printing come out without any similar fault ever since.
Simple but solve the problem.

description.text:
This is a German Panther tank.

The model is about 19cm long, 9.5cm wide and 8cm high.

It has good details and requires a lot of assembly. It features a flexible tracks, movable turret and main gun.

It also has a room for you to insert an engine!

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

For the tracks, they have to be printed with flexible material.

There are total of 32 road wheels,16 on each side.
8 sets on one side, one set has an inner wheel and an outer wheel.
There are 4 gears and 4 idles.

Print more road wheels and gears in case some of them fail.

Assembly

The barrel is a steel bar of 4mm diameter. I has a plastic shaft (ink of a pen) to serve as the rotating axis for the main gun.

Paperclip is used for the machine gun.

4mm screws are used as the shafts for all the road wheels and idler gears.

You will need 20 screws as shafts.

title: 5/16 (8mm) Rod Based MultiWii Quadcopter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
There are a lot of other quads here on Thingiverse. I started by building the Pl2Q Hugin by Swepet but I routinely was crashing it hard enough to break its arms. I decided to migrate to something a bit more able to bounce without breaking and be faster to fix even when I do crash. The electronic setup of this is the one I used from my Hugin and is heavily based on Swepetâ€™s work on the PL1Q Vampire. The frame of this is a continuation of Octovirâ€™s work on his carbon fiber arrow shaft based frame for an Arducopter. Unlike many of the quads here I can say exactly what parts I purchased and used in this if other wants to make one from scratch. I have had a few catastrophic crashes and even in the worst cash Iâ€™ve had the quad repaired faster than Iâ€™ve had the battery recharged. This even includes print time of new parts when required. Originally I wanted to go with aluminum arms but sourcing 5/16 aluminum rod locally wasnâ€™t possible. I used left over tool steel rods from building my printer and even with that weight it flew fine. Those were a bit on the over kill side so now that Iâ€™ve toned down my rate of hard landings Iâ€™ve switched to all wooden dowels. It only takes ~5mins to replace a broken arm now and ~30mins to reprint and replace a leg both of which cost less than $.25. The frame is considerably more rugged then I thought it would be. In my worst crash I nailed a tree at full speed 3 stories up and it tumbled straight down. I saw that it landed right side up so I just gave it a go on taking off again and it was still able to fly around. I ended up breaking 2 wooden pieces, a leg and mangled a prop bad enough it needed replacing. Even with all that damage and the battery dangling loose below it, it could fly. On the limping, wobbly side but stillâ€¦ Even that was fixed before the battery was charged. I tried to make the legs shock absorbing and I can tell you that subjectively it can crash fairly hard and still be undamaged. Update 7/23/12:
I added a new version of the legs. When I originally tested them I made them such that in hard crashes the leg and the wooden arm would break at about a 1:1 rate and then backed a bit off the leg strength since I would rather replace the legs. I decided to make the legs a bit stronger now since I havenâ€™t broken an arm in a while but I still go through a number of legs. Update 10/24/12:
Added my camera mount. It's based on the 808 camera mount by kenwshmt; which is now in the ancestors list. STL added in the top level of the easy to print (support-less but will need glue to assemble) print I used. Glue-less and separate pieces STL's are included with the scad in the zip. You will need the STL from kenwshmt's thing to render the scad directly. The camera I'm using was purchased from the supplier in kenwshmt's thing. It's only a $10 camera and has quality that's representative of that. That is to say that it's perfectly adequate for a flight recorder but don't plan on any nice photography. Sample video from on board camera: http://youtu.be/sxnny5DqIak

Step 1: Acquire the following Printed parts:
4x Outer connector by Octovir (see ancestry)
4x Frame Vertex with Integrated Motor Mount by Octovir (see ancestry)

http://www.goodluckbuy.com/a2208-17-1000kv-outrunner-brushless-motor-for-rc-helicopter-multicopter-4-pack.html

http://www.completeheli.com/Gaui-330X-8-Propellers-8A-8B-Neon-Green-G-210802 Total $248.56 Local Parts:

description.header: 4 or M3 screws for frame assembly
description.text:
Shrink Tube
Velcro Note: Consider ordering a spare set of props. You will need them if you are learning to fly. Step 2: Read (Skim?) the documentation My radio and Multiwii board did not come with documentation. The following are decent resources online for getting wiring and software setting information.
NEWBIES GUIDE to setting up and using the CRIUS MWC MultiWii SE Board Software By ATXHELI
http://homepage3.nifty.com/aohp/local/hikoukim/Newbies%20Guide%20to%20CRIUS%20MultiWii%20SE%20board%20and%20software.pdf
RadioLink T6EHP manual http://www.radiolink.com.cn/doce/download-downloads-1.html
You will also need to consult the printed instructions that come with the speed controllers. Step 3: Do the ESC+motor wiring The ESC to motor wiring can be arbitrary for now. Switching around the 3 wires will only change to direction of rotation. The arms are about 9in long and I recommend you leave some slack. As long as you are using connectors, which you should be, just put it together randomly for now and fix it later. All of the ESCs power connectors should be in parallel to the battery connector. The battery I received uses a deanâ€™s connector which is available at local R/C hobby shops. Donâ€™t worry about hooking up the MultiWii board or the radio receiver for now. Step 4: Setup the software Iâ€™m using MultiWii v2.0. Itâ€™s available from their Google code site at http://code.google.com/p/multiwii/downloads/detail?name=MultiWii_2_0.zip&can=2&q=
If youâ€™re unfamiliar with flashing microcontrollers I suggest you read some documentation from the Arduino project. If youâ€™re running a 3d printer, youâ€™re probably fine. The Crius board is essentially an Arduino with an Atmega328P and an FTDI chip. The drivers and tools needed to flash the board are all included with the Arduino software. You will want to program the speed controllers while they are all connected in parallel to make sure they are all set the same. When connecting them in parallel, which you will also do when they are connected to the MultiWii, you will need to clip the center [red] wire out of all but one connector. Use some pin header to make a programming adapter. As seen here http://imgur.com/J4kBM. You will want to set the throttle range and disable low voltage turn off. Note: My radio had the throttle stick inverted by default. You may need to account for that in your programming technique. Also note that the ESCs use the motors to play tones. You should connect the motors so that you can hear the ESCs feedback. Step 5: Build the frame and mount the motors Everything went together easily and smoothly with only a few minor exceptions. Since I could only get M3 screws locally in one length (10mm), all of the motor mount screws had to be through only the top part of each vertex (missing 1 hole on 1 in each vertex). The rods give you a substantial amount of play in how square the frame comes out. The screws in the outer vertexes shake themselves out and need to be installed tightly. The center piece on mine has loose screws and is holding together fine. Use Velcro to hold the ESCs onto their tabs on the center and for receiver mounting on the bottom. My battery is mounted in a bit of a clunky way. I have a piece of cardboard with holes punched for the screws and nuts hot glue to the bottom with Velcro on it. When installing the legs you will want to soften them with a heat gun and add a touch of hot glue to prevent them from rotating. Step 6: Check motor directions and install props One by one connect each ESC to the throttle channel of the receiver and see which direction it spins. A piece of tape on the shaft makes it easier to see. Since you probably clipped the center wire out of 3 of them, you will need to connect the one with the power wire to some other channel on the receiver while testing those 3. Consult the diagram in the above pdf for the desired direction of each motor. On any that spin the other way switch any two of the three wires going to the motor. This is a fine time to connect the correct prop to each motor. Step 7: Install and configure the MultiWii Board Screw the MultiWii board to the standoffs using sheet metal or similar screws. You may want to drill down the guide holes to get a better fit depending on how it printed. Snap the standoffs into their holes. If itâ€™s a loose fit use a drop of hot glue to hold them down. Connect the receiver to the MultiWii board as directed in the pdfs above; I wouldnâ€™t bother with the ESCs yet. Connect the board to your computer and run the configuration software. You will want to check that each of your control sticks is going over a correct range and has a correct center point. Use the trim settings or the software in the radio to adjust if required. I also turned down the sensitivity to around 1/3 of its default value (as detailed in the pdf) and it still feels too sensitive to me. You should also put it on a level surface and use the calibration tools. Note: You will want to use AUX1 even though the package did not contain enough wire to hook it up. AUX1 is used to toggle stable mode which you will probably want to use. DO NOT SKIP AUX1.
DO NOT SKIP AUX1. Step 8: Test fly Connect all wires to the board as directed in the pdf. I highly suggest you tether it so that it canâ€™t really move or get more than a foot or so up. My first flight had the throttle sensitivity way out of whack and the quad shot up way out of control. Look at the stick commands in the pdf. You will notice that just turning the throttle up will NOT start the motors. You should use the stick based calibration commands too. In this flight you will be mostly looking at control sensitivity, accuracy of your calibration, and most importantly inverted axis in your controls. You should now be tuned well enough to fly and more tuning is out of scope here. TL;DR Itâ€™s easy. Just go for it.

description.text:
Neither of the 2 sources fit with my z-brace mod (the backing was to long) so I resized it shorter and also reversed it in case anyone was routing their cables to the other side (Like I was). I also filled in a screw hole on each side instead of using double sided tape. You might have to open the hole more as I made it to small and didn't feel like redoing it (I know I'm lazy tonight)

I decided to publish in case anyone else had the same issue.

Make sure you use a longer screw probably 5/6mm to replace the one you remove to mount the "plate" to the back.

The files included are:
1x Resized back plate with screw hole
1x Resized back plate without screw hole
1x Resized Cover
1x Resized and Reversed back plate with screw hole
1x Resized and Reversed back plate without screw hole
1x Resized and Reversed Cover

(Follow original for printing instructions) https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2486494
The shrouds will need to be rotated and printed flat side down. I didn't do it in the stl file.

UPDATE

Not sure how I missed this, I fixed the Reversed Conduit Shroud. It had 2 tabs disconnected. (goofed during merging of meshes) It's fixed now and the file is uploaded.

Another Update
Added 6 more files similar named. This time I put both wire holes on one side (my setup has both wire bundles going to one side. If I moved them it would seriously stretch them out. They are labeled as "OneSided_A" and "OneSided_B" nab the one you need if you need them.

Enjoy.

title: Ravyn Open Flywheel Project Cages Embossed
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
For the people who print multiple cages I have embossed the size on the bottom of the cage. This is useful if you are swapping out multiple cages so you can quickly identify what spacing is on a given cage.

This is an opensource flywheel cage created for the Nerf Ravyn.

There are four versions of this cage poster here, for highest performance print the 41.5 mm cage. Each cage larger has decreasing performance related to the gap distance listed in the file name.

For high crush systems such as the 41.5 mm and 42 mm cages, motors with very high torque ratings are required.

To learn more about Open Flywheel Project please visit http://openflywheelproject.com/

Printer:

title: Fusebox-Hypercube Hybrid for FLSUN cube hardware
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I've posted these parts since I know the adapter works, I linked the other parts that I used, will give a shopping list of the parts used (only about 30-50 bucks for bearings from amazon)

be sure to configure marlin with your settings and features, I would use marlin-config as it is easy to use and see changes (https://github.com/akaJes/marlin-config/releases)

essentially this combines the hypercube's x carriage with the fusebox 2's idler and mounting setup so it can reduce the needed material costs, be compatible with the 400mm x rails that dont work with a hypercube nor the fusebox due to them being too far away and the 500mm y rails that don't work with how the hypercube mounts their 300mm rails.

the new x rail adapter allows for the 400mm rails to be used on a fusebox setup, but at a distance apart that works with a hypercube carriage that allows for any hypercube accessory to be used on a FLSUN cube with Core XY at the least cost

*note i changed the CC to non commercial and share alike to allow for all parts to be posted at once, look into what parts you are printing from the project if you want to use it for such. (direct from hypercube parts, direct bracket parts, any remix of the fan duct or old sensor mount)

Printer:

any that can print high stress tolerent plastc

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

40% hex

Notes:

as long as you do 0.2 with base supports on the xy joiners (first two parts) you should be fine on any printer, my cube's parts broke so I used a local makerspace to print these parts, although it took ~200 grams for a full 1mm thick wall setup since I could only use PLA instead of my usual petg that I will use for the cooling parts after this.
the orange parts where on the replicator when my acrylic flsun default parts where broken, the new white, yellow, and petg green parts where added.

comments.text: I'm curious why you chose to cantilever the x axis off the two rods on one side of the y axis rather than locate one rod at each end of the x axis?  Am I missing some advantage?  Generally, hanging something from two wide spaced rails reduces sag and stress on the system as compared to cantilevering, no?  I'm certainly not an engineer, but this is what I thought.
comments.author: Rethys

comments.text:
both ends of the two y and x axis rods are firmly fixed to the corners and the xy joiners respectively, initially the x rails are not due to an issue with the fusebox2's bearing holder being in the way if you replace the rails.
since the rod holders are stiff on the slightly oversized rods, they need to be set parallel by only fixing one point on each side until they run smooth, then are both tightened and attached to the y bearing block.
now that both are parallel and secured to each other, I don't think there will be an issue, but I think it has more to do with extending z range by moving the rail plane slightly above the center between the rails.

title: Tile Mate Bluetooth Tracker - Protective Case and Anti-Pocket-Presser

description.text:
I love my Tile Mate Bluetooth tracker, but it has a serious design flaw. When I place it on my keyring and put my keys in my pocket, it goes off by accident all the time. I ran the batteries down after six months because of accidental button-presses, and the Mate is supposed to last a whole year.

So I made this protective case that reduces the chance of keys and other things pushing up against the button in your pocket. So far it has worked great!

It also helps protect your Tile and does not reduce the range.

Use the Cura feature "Horizontal Expansion" to get your parts to fit snugly. Make sure the keychain hole is aligned correctly and simply snap together.

If your pieces won't fit together, you need to calibrate your printer or use "Horizontal expansion" or "print exterior first".

description.text:
This is a flexible tripod for Galaxy S4 (can be adapted to any phone).
Usage: http://youtu.be/tMLmO11TfsE
I have designed it for my own phone for usage in extreme snow kiteboarding sessions because in past we have a lot of shaking video (http://youtu.be/URNIPVCqAkk?t=12m58s) Source code on github: https://github.com/chertykov/Tripod I have used:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:9095
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:8796

I have printed it on Prusa i3 with:
  • slic3r (is nicer ;-)
  • 0.4mm noozle
  • 0.25mm layer thikness
  • 30% infill
    • To assemble the tripod I have printed:
  • segment.stl (for three legs) 10*3 = 30. You can choose different count of segments.
  • tensioner.stl x 3
  • plate.stl x 1 (accurate printing required because of built in ball joint. I have used 40mm/sec printing speed)
  • clamp.stl x 3
  • phone-mount.stl x 1 - print it with support. (Redesign it for your phone/camera)
    • Also you need:
  • one rubber O ring to tightening three clamps
  • strong fishing line or something non stretch (I have used kite lines)

comments.text:

title: 28mm pole bracket for filament storage box

description.text:
I had 28mm wooden pole left over from some project, so I modified jasonharper's brackets to fit them. I also made back plates to work as washers and countersunk for wood screws I had around. Back plate also has label of what is inside. There are ready versions for PLA, ABS, PET-G and Flex. Also included is back plate with no label.

Smaller version of bracket holds easily 5kg of filament and is faster to print than the original.

Remember to drill holes to the container, those type of boxes crack easily if you screw through them. Insert Silica gel to the bottom of the box, since your spools are hanging from the pole, you can pour silica gel pellets in there without any containment which weaken the effect of it.
You can also add print straight from this storage box, either with just opening the lid or do this: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2172384

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/gTszm6iNZBg

Klein bottle is a closed manifold that does not have topside or underside. From any spot on the surface you can walk to the opposite side of the spot without crossing the edge.

See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Klein_bottle for details.

Please do not dislocate your brain thinking about it!

I liked the design, but thought it was too thin. I mirrored the object in Slic3r and glued the halves together. Works well and has enough weight to toss across the room.

Thanks to elvisior for the design.

description.text:

First I did a 90(ish) degree outlet, but then decided I wanted something a bit more gentle that wouldn't upset all the CO2 I inject into my outlet.

Enter this outlet bell!

Dilberately non-symmentrical - Invert it to provide more/less agitation.

Enjoy!

description.text:
Simple light bar for CR-10. Uses an inexpensive Ikea Dioder light bar kit.

Snap and interference fit. Used electrical tape to hold the light bars in place for the photo, but should use double sided tape or hot glue or clip if you want to design one (elec tape works fine though).

The standoffs provide plenty of room to keep the full 400mm Z travel.

I hid the power wire under the orange trim piece (I removed the trim from the front uprights and re-purposed)

Dioder is soft white, so may not be bright enough for everyone. You can simply print a mounting plate and install in place of Dioders and tape/glue any led light ribbon you want (I did not include a design for this).

title: Tactile Picture Book Happy Sad Faces

description.text:
PRINT: Print was perfect. I actually reduced it to 50 percent and it became like a little pocket book, which was cool.
No supports
infill is needed but I will leave that to your discretion as I work with 20-40%.

INFORMATION:
Loved the Noah's Ark Tactile Picture Book and had a family that had some specific requests.

  • They wanted to make it into a book
    *I placed wholes on the sides in order to thread yarn or use those metal ring brakets to make a book.

  • The braille dots on Noah's Ark are way way to rough for their child and poke/catch everything.

    • removed braille areas and slimmed down the design which helped make it into a book format.
  • Quick and easy to teach with.
    • I placed happy and sad so the child could learn and point easily. They are placed in opposite ends with a top to bottom, so when you open the book, you will know their placements and understand them better.
      Only used 2 faces to simplify learning.

MANY MORE IDEAS, BUT TIME IS A HARD COMMODITY. If you would like more, I can make more with specific images and with braille if needed/desired.

title: Best MK2 Spool Holder with 608ZZ Bearings
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Probably the 100th remix of MK2 spool holders on Thingiverse, but I still didn't find one exactly to my liking. Maybe some of you will also choose this over others!

My goal was to have minimal gap between the spool tube, and the conical adapter for the MK2 spool arm, while utilizing 2x 608ZZ bearings for a buttery smooth roll. Other designs required all new spool arms (I liked my orange ones), required more bearings or were too wide for my taste.

What You'll Need:
-2x 608zz bearings (I think any 608/608z/608zz will work)
-A working 3-D printer (duh, that's what we do)

Print Suggestions:
-Printing the tube @ full height will yield a ~120mm tube length
-Printing @ 85% Z height yields ~103mm tube WHICH IS WHAT IS PICTURED (the bearing fit is just fine at either height)
Anything between 85-100% Z height should work, and most spools are under 90mm wide.
-.2 layer height worked great for me, but you could go for more detail if you'd like.
-I have been messing with honeycomb infill lately, and printed these at 25%
-The tube is already prepared with a taper for the bottom recess, don't mess with it!

Post-Print Suggestions:
The bottom openings may require a bit of a run around the holes with an exacto for everything to slide in smoothly. I also recommend sanding the outside of the spool tube as best you can; I cheated and shoved it over something on my drill to do some high speed power sanding!

The ideal fit would be for the bearings to stay retained on the adapters, and for the adapters to remain retained on the spool holder arms so that only the spool tube is free when changing rolls. Mine were a tight press fit for both side of the adapter, and a "snug" but easily removable fit on the tube!

The ideal fit would be for the bearings to stay retained on the adapters, and for the adapters to remain retained on the spool holder arms so that only the spool tube is free when changing rolls. Mine were a tight press fit for both side of the adapter, and a "snug" but easily removable fit on the tube!

author: Thailston

title: Raspberry Pi Camera Mount - ring magnet & M4x6mm

description.text:
A mount for the IR raspberry pi camera, minus the IR LED's.
Simple to attach anywhere to a (ferrous) metal frame. I prefer the Z carriage on my i3, so the camera raises as the Z axis does. I target the top of the print, so it is always what is in centre frame.
Rotate fairly freely to desired angle.
Pulls away if anything snags it.
Simple and stupid. I have tried to find the ideal camera attachment for a long time, this is just my way of giving up and going for the simplest possible solution I can think of at this point in time.

Needs:

  • 1x M4 button capped bolt, the black 'high tensile' ones (the shiny ones aren't very magnetically useful).
  • 1x Neodymium magnet N50 10mm x 3mm & 3mm countersunk hole. Or several for additional holding force and offsetting the camera POV a bit.
    https://www.ebay.com.au/sch/sis.html?_nkw=Magnet+10+mm+X+3+mm+Countersunk+Hole%3A3mm+Rare+Earth+Neodymium+N50
  • 4x M1.5 x5mm self tapping screws... or whatever size usually screws a raspicam into a housing.

Herp Derp.

  • Screw the M4 into the side of the housing, stick the magnet to something metal, stick the camera onto the magnet via the rounded bolt head, adjust angle.
  • I have a square of innertube rubber between the printer frame and the magnet, to give it more friction and prevent it from sliding around.

Notes:
  • The case has a very large surface area touching the build plate. Take appropriate measures (glue stick, painters tape, etc.)so that you can get it off. You might also want to use a brim to avoid warping depending on your material.
  • The case is optional if you have another Pi case and don't mind the wires.
  • If you're careful, you can get everything to friction fit, but it depends on the tolerance of your printer and the specific parts you're using. Before printing, you should check measurements for:
    • barrel jack port (6mm)
    • armature wire holes (3.5mm w/ 0.1mm tolerance)
    • LED mounting holes (2mm holes, 8mm apart)
    • globe bottom diameter (98.5mm)
  • If anything measures out differently, then use OpenSCAD to adjust the models.

remixed_from.title: Anet A8 - Anti Z Wobbel TNG (Set)

title: Parametric X idler lift (Z wobble elimination) in OpenSCAD
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
In order to eliminate or minimize the effect of the threaded rod wobble that moves the carriage in Z direction one could opt for the separation of the X-axis and Z-axis movement by introducing a mechanical spilt between these movements in the form of a lifting block. I've used these in the past and helped me to get better quality parts. This design differs as such that it is a parametric design that could be tailored to your needs. Parameters in this design are e.g. the center to center distance of the guide and threaded rod, height of the lift, guide rod shaft diameter.

Note that the source is added for you to change to your needs. Once you changed the parameters to your needs, generate an STL file for slicing.

I've designed this part to be used on a larger version of a Prusa i3 style printer to hold a 200x300 bed size. A rework of the X-idlers has been posted here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2579666

Note that the Xidler lifting devices are inspired by the parts:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2067676
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1858459
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:808509

Design

The design and sizing of the lifting devices is based on the X-idler dimensions found at https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2579666

A combined view of the x-idler lifting devices and the rework on the x-idlers is shown in the assembly figures

title: Taz 1-6 Y motor upper bearing shaft protector anti break thingy of doom (w/ optional reinforced motor mount)

description.text:
This is a "hat" that fits over the top of the Lulzbot Taz Y axis motor mount that allows a 14 mm dia x 5mm thick x 5mm shaft 605zz bearing to fit on the upper portion of the shaft just above the belt mount.

This project also includes a remix of the Lulzbot taz Y axis motor mount variant 2.4 (which will fit a taz 1-5) It is reinforced in several places, has smaller mounting holes for the motor, some clearance for a motor vibration damper, reinforced sides and gussets, and space down below for a future cable path mounting cover thing that doesn't yet exist. you will need 2 M2 heat set inserts and 2 m3 heat set inserts to fully leverage those features. the motor mount is however optional and can be ignored if you just want the bearing thingy. The hat will fit a Taz 6, the optional mount will not fit a 6.

Development thread here:
https://forum.lulzbot.com/viewtopic.php?f=16&t=6846

To use: source 2mm longer m3 motor mount bolts. Insert the M3 and M2 heat set inserts into the optional motor mount in the usual way. Use the stock mounting hardware to attach the motor mount and limit switch. Stick the bearing in the top of the cap, bolt everything down, and you're all set.

comments.text: By having the motor shaft constrained in the bearing, you make the dampener somewhat useless !
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: No, not even a little. The motor is still mounted to the upper layer of the vibration isolation material and the motor mount is located in the lower layer. The bearing doesn't constrain the shaft in the Z axis, so it is free to release the vibrational energy in that axis. The upper section itself can also be further vibration isolated if you wish, but the entire point of the vibration isolation pad is to prevent motor vibration transfer into the frame, which this device does not prevent. Are you losing maybe 1% efficiency here? sure. but overall the added mass to the custom mount and the reduced strain on the shaft should actually reduce vibration more than any loss you might incur,
comments.author: MKSA
